title: 'Big fail, Everlane': Bloggers call out brand for lack of sizing at Nordstrom pop-up
text:
A Canadian swimwear designer is urging retailers to deliver on their promise to be size inclusive - both in-store and online.

Julia Church said she was initially excited to learn that sustainable fashion brand Everlane was headed north for a pop-up event at Nordstrom Canada. Without a brick and mortar location in Canada, many fans of the American retailer, like Church, rely on Everlane’s online store and pay shipping and duty on international orders.

ALSO SEE: #TrendOnTrial: What is brow lamination—and is it worth it?

When the Vancouver-based founder of Nettle’s Tale, a size inclusive swimwear line, headed to her local Nordstrom to check out the temporary pop-up, she was disheartened to find that despite carrying up to a size 20 online, the Everlane pop-up only carried up to a size 12 in store.

Julia Church. Image via Nettle's Tale. More

Although she said she’s a customer and fan of the brand’s commitment to transparency and sustainability, Church reportedly tried to contact Everlane via email to express her frustrations. When no contact information for the pop-up could be found, she turned to Instagram stories to share her disappointment.

ALSO SEE: Sophie Grégoire Trudeau celebrates Liberal win in eco-friendly $249 dress

“Big fail Everlane,” Church said. “When you offer up to a certain size and you announce that you’re offering that size, and then you don’t have over a size 12 available at your pop-up, you’ve got your size 16, size 18, 20 women going to that pop up saying, ‘Hey do you have anything over a size 12 here?’ You have to make eye contact with a complete stranger as they look into your eyes and they’re like, ‘I’m so sorry we don’t have over a size 12 here.’”

Image via Everlane. More

Church went on to explain how “demoralizing” it can be for both parties involved, with staff offering alternatives that make the shopper uncomfortable.

“They start to announce, ‘Try this piece on - it’s extra roomy, it runs big.’ And then they wait outside of the change room,” She continued. “I’m not going to come out of the change room, I’m trying to gauge my size here and I can’t get any of the pants done up. I made an evening of this and now I feel really bad about myself when you actually offer my size. You could have just had it at your pop-up so I could have tried it on and had a good experience.”

ALSO SEE: 'It was time to stop hiding': How shaving her head helped this blogger embrace her 'inner warrior'

Church left Nordstrom’s empty handed but said she still went home to place an online order from Everlane. She went on to credit blogger Shannon Buckley for helping women who are over a size 12 feel comfortable shopping online sharing her measurements and try-on hauls with her more than 50,000 Instagram followers.

Story continues
description: "Now I feel really bad about myself when you actually offer my size."
